Instruction: How does the DMV determine the eligibility of an individual for a waiver?
Output:
For current or former military service members, the DMV determines eligibility for a waiver based on specific conditions and limitations. To be eligible, the applicant must certify and provide evidence that, during the 1-year period immediately before applying, they:
*   Were regularly employed in a military position requiring operation of a passenger CMV (if seeking a passenger endorsement waiver), operation of a tank vehicle (if seeking a tank vehicle endorsement waiver), or transportation of hazardous materials (if seeking a hazardous materials endorsement waiver).
*   Did not simultaneously hold more than one civilian license (in addition to a military license).
*   Have not had any license suspended, revoked, or cancelled.
*   Have not had any convictions for disqualifying offenses as defined in § 383.51(b).
*   Have not had more than one conviction for serious traffic violations as defined in § 383.51(c).
*   Have not had any convictions for traffic violations (other than parking) or been at fault in a crash.
For a knowledge test waiver for a CLP or CDL, the military service member must certify and provide evidence that, during the 1-year period before application, they:
*   Were regularly employed and designated as a Motor Transport Operator, PATRIOT Launching Station Operator, Fueler, Vehicle Operator, Pavement and Construction Equipment Operator, or Motor Vehicle Operator (specific military codes apply).
*   Operated a vehicle representative of the CMV type they expect to operate after leaving the military.
*   Meet the same conditions regarding licenses, convictions, and traffic violations as above.
For a driving skills test waiver, the applicant must:
*   Provide evidence and certify that they are currently or were regularly employed in a military position requiring CMV operation within the last year.
*   Were exempt from CDL requirements under § 383.3(c).
*   Were operating a vehicle representative of the CMV type for at least two years before separating from the military.
*   Meet the same conditions regarding licenses, convictions, and traffic violations as above, but for a 2-year period instead of 1 year.

Instruction: What is the process for obtaining a waiver?
Output:
The process for obtaining a waiver depends on the type of waiver you are seeking.
Military Knowledge Test Waiver:
For current or former military service members, a state may waive the requirement to pass the knowledge test for a Commercial Learner's Permit (CLP) or Commercial Driver's License (CDL) if the applicant meets specific conditions. The service member must certify and provide evidence that, in the one-year period before applying, they were regularly employed in a military position as a Motor Transport Operator (Army 88M), PATRIOT Launching Station Operator (Army 14T), Fueler (Army 92F), Vehicle Operator (Air Force 2T1), Fueler (Air Force 2F0), Pavement and Construction Equipment Operator (Air Force 3E2), Motor Vehicle Operator (Marine Corps 3531), or Equipment Operator (Navy E.O.). They must also be operating a vehicle representative of the CMV type they expect to operate after leaving the military, held no more than one civilian license in addition to their military license, have had no license suspensions, revocations, or cancellations, have no convictions for disqualifying offenses or more than one conviction for serious traffic violations, and have no convictions for traffic violations related to a crash where they were at fault.
Military Skills Test Waiver:
A state may waive the requirement for military service members to pass a driving skills test and specialized knowledge test for a passenger (P) endorsement, the knowledge test for a tank vehicle (N) endorsement, or the knowledge test for a hazardous materials (H) endorsement. The service member must certify that in the year before applying, they were regularly employed in a military position requiring operation of a passenger CMV (for a passenger endorsement waiver), operation of a tank vehicle (for a tank vehicle endorsement waiver), or transportation of hazardous materials (for a hazardous materials endorsement waiver). They must also meet the same conditions regarding licenses, convictions, and traffic violations as mentioned above for the knowledge test waiver.
DUI Hearing Fee Waiver:
In some states, if you are requesting a hearing related to a Driving Under the Influence (DUI) offense, you may apply for a waiver of the hearing fee if you are indigent and your income is below the federal poverty threshold. To apply, you typically need to submit a request for a DUI hearing and a DUI Administrative Hearing Fee Waiver Application. You may also need to provide additional information to determine your eligibility.

Instruction: What is the process for obtaining a waiver for the standard ID card?
Output:
As of California Vehicle Code sections 12801.5 and 12801.9, you can obtain an original standard ID card, even if you cannot provide proof that your presence in the United States is authorized under federal law, if you can provide satisfactory proof of identity and California residency. The DMV will accept various types of documentation for this purpose, including but not limited to:
*   A valid, unexpired consular identification document issued by a consulate from the applicant’s country of citizenship, or a valid, unexpired passport from the applicant’s country of citizenship.
*   An original birth certificate, or other proof of age, as designated by the department.
*   A home utility bill, lease or rental agreement, or other proof of California residence, as designated by the department.
*   If not in English, a marriage license or divorce certificate accompanied by a certified translation or an affidavit of translation into English.
*   If not in English, a foreign federal electoral photo card issued on or after January 1, 1991, accompanied by a certified translation or an affidavit of translation into English.
*   If not in English, a foreign driver’s license accompanied by a certified translation or an affidavit of translation into English.
*   A United States Department of Homeland Security Form I-589, Application for Asylum and for Withholding of Removal.
*   If not in English, an official school or college transcript that includes the applicant’s date of birth or a foreign school record that is sealed and includes a photograph of the applicant at the age the record was issued, accompanied by a certified translation or an affidavit of translation into English.
*   A United States Department of Homeland Security Form I-20 or Form DS-2019.
*   A deed or title to real property.
*   A property tax bill or statement issued within the previous 12 months.
*   An income tax return.
An identification card issued under these provisions will bear the notice: “This card is not acceptable for official federal purposes. This identification card is issued only as a means of identification. It does not establish eligibility for employment, voter registration, or public benefits.”

Knowledge Test Waiver:

-Were regularly employed and designated as a Motor Transport Operator—88M (Army), PATRIOT Launching Station Operator—14T (Army), Fueler—92F (Army), Vehicle Operator—2T1 (Air Force), Fueler—2F0 (Air Force), Pavement and Construction Equipment Operator—3E2 (Air Force), Motor Vehicle Operator—3531 (Marine Corps), or Equipment Operator—E.O. (Navy).
-Operated a vehicle representative of the CMV type they expect to operate, or operated such a vehicle type immediately preceding separation from the military.
-Have not simultaneously held more than one civilian license (in addition to a military license).
-Have not had any license suspended, revoked, or cancelled.
-Have not had any convictions for disqualifying offenses as contained in § 383.51(b).
-Have not had more than one conviction for serious traffic violations as contained in § 383.51(c).
-Have not had any conviction for a violation of military, State, or local law relating to motor vehicle traffic control (other than a parking violation) arising in connection with any traffic accident, and has no record of an accident in which they were at fault.
Driving Skills Test Waiver:

-Provide evidence and certify that they are regularly employed or were regularly employed within the last year in a military position requiring operation of a CMV.

-Certify that, during the 2-year period immediately prior to applying for a CDL, they:

In California, according to Vehicle Code section 12801.9, the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) shall issue an identification card to a person who is unable to submit satisfactory proof that the applicant’s presence in the United States is authorized under federal law if the person provides satisfactory proof to the department of the person’s identity and California residency. The law does not explicitly deny an ID card or certification based solely on an individual's criminal record. The DMV may require the applicant to provide documentation to verify their identity and residency.

This information must be verified by presentation of proof of identity satisfactory to the department. The department must accept as satisfactory proof of identity under this subsection an offender identification card or similar form of identification issued to an inmate by the Texas Department of Criminal Justice if the applicant also provides supplemental verifiable records or documents that aid in establishing identity.

Instruction: What is the process for obtaining a waiver for the farm labor vehicle certificate?
Output:
In California, a person issued a driver’s license by the Department of Motor Vehicles is exempt from the endorsement requirements of Section 15275 if they meet specific conditions. These conditions include being employed in an agricultural operation, driving a vehicle controlled by a farmer (excluding vehicles used in common or contract motor carriage), and transporting agricultural products, farm machinery, or supplies to or from a farm.
To obtain this exemption, the following steps must be completed:
1.  Training: Fulfill the training requirements of Subpart H of Part 172 of Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations.
2.  Verification of Training: Upon completing the training, a record of current training and a completed application must be sent to the Department of the California Highway Patrol (CHP). The CHP will issue a verification of training, valid for three years, to be carried while operating the vehicle.
3.  Submission to DMV: Within 15 days of the CHP’s issuance, a copy of the verification must be sent to the DMV for inclusion on the person's permanent driving record, along with a fee of $12.
4.  Informational Material: The person must have informational material approved by the CHP, in both English and Spanish, outlining basic safety procedures in the event of an accident. The CHP will provide this information at no cost.
5.  Vehicle and Distance Requirements: The vehicle being operated must be an implement of husbandry or a motor vehicle requiring only a class C driver’s license, and the distance the vehicle is operated must not exceed 50 miles between the final point of distribution and the ultimate point of application, or between parts of a farm, or from one farm to another.
6.  Medical Information: Instead of a medical examination report, the applicant must submit medical information on a form approved by the DMV upon application and every two years thereafter. Note that if the person does not meet the medical requirements for a hazardous materials endorsement, they are not qualified to transport hazardous materials.

Knowledge test waivers for certain current or former military service members applying for a CLP or CDL require that the applicant certify and provide evidence that, during the 1-year period immediately prior to the application, he/she:

*Has not had any convictions for any type of motor vehicle for the disqualifying offenses contained in § 383.51(b).

Driving skills test waivers for certain current or former military service members applying for a CDL require that the applicant provide evidence and certify that he/she:

*Has not had any convictions for any type of motor vehicle for the disqualifying offenses contained in § 383.51(b).

Endorsement waivers for certain current or former military service members applying for a CLP or a CDL require that the applicant certify and provide evidence that, during the 1-year period immediately prior to the application, he/she:

*Has not had any convictions for any type of motor vehicle for the disqualifying offenses contained in § 383.51(b).

Instruction: What is the process for obtaining a waiver?
Output:
The process for obtaining a waiver depends on the type of waiver you are seeking.
Military Knowledge Test Waiver:
For current or former military service members, a state may waive the requirement to pass the knowledge test for a Commercial Learner's Permit (CLP) or Commercial Driver's License (CDL) if the applicant meets specific conditions. The service member must certify and provide evidence that, during the one-year period before applying, they were regularly employed in a military position as a Motor Transport Operator (88M - Army), PATRIOT Launching Station Operator (14T - Army), Fueler (92F - Army), Vehicle Operator (2T1 - Air Force), Fueler (2F0 - Air Force), Pavement and Construction Equipment Operator (3E2 - Air Force), Motor Vehicle Operator (3531 - Marine Corps), or Equipment Operator (E.O. - Navy). They must also be operating a vehicle representative of the CMV type they expect to operate after leaving the military, have no more than one civilian license (in addition to a military license), and have no license suspensions, revocations, or cancellations. Additionally, they must not have any convictions for disqualifying offenses or more than one conviction for serious traffic violations, and no convictions for traffic violations related to a crash where they were at fault.
Military Skills Test Waiver:
A state may waive the requirement for military service members to pass a driving skills test and specialized knowledge test for a passenger (P) endorsement, the knowledge test for a tank vehicle (N) endorsement, or the knowledge test for a hazardous materials (H) endorsement. The applicant must certify and provide evidence that, during the one-year period before the application, they were regularly employed in a military position requiring the operation of a passenger CMV, a tank vehicle, or the transportation of hazardous materials. They must also meet the same conditions regarding licenses, convictions, and traffic violations as mentioned above.
DUI Hearing Fee Waiver:
In some states, such as Washington, you can apply for a waiver of the $375 DUI hearing fee if you are found to be indigent and have an income below the poverty threshold. To apply, you must submit a Request for DUI Hearing form, a DUI Administrative Hearing Fee Waiver Application, and potentially an Additional Eligibility Determination form.

Instruction: How long does it take to process a waiver application?
Output: The processing time for a waiver application depends on the type of waiver. For a DUI Administrative Hearing Fee Waiver in Washington, the processing time is not specified, but you will be notified in writing regarding your eligibility.

Instruction: What is the criteria for determining the cost of a waiver?
Output:
For a DUI hearing fee waiver, the criteria are: indigence as defined by state law and an income below the federal poverty cut-off level. For 2025, the federal poverty guidelines are: 1 person in family/household: $15,650 annual income or $1,304 monthly income; 2 people: $21,150 annual income or $1,763 monthly income; 3 people: $26,650 annual income or $2,221 monthly income; 4 people: $32,150 annual income or $2,679 monthly income; 5 people: $37,650 annual income or $3,138 monthly income; 6 people: $43,150 annual income or $3,596 monthly income; 7 people: $48,659 annual income or $4,055 monthly income; 8 people: $54,150 annual income or $4,513 monthly income. For each additional person above 8, add $5,500 annually.
For current or former military service members applying for a Commercial Driver's License (CDL), the conditions and limitations are:
*   During the 1-year period immediately prior to the application, he/she:
    *   Is or was regularly employed in a military position requiring operation of a passenger CMV, if the applicant is requesting a waiver of the knowledge and driving skills test for a passenger endorsement; operation of a tank vehicle, if the applicant is requesting a waiver of the knowledge test for a tank vehicle endorsement; or transportation of hazardous materials, if the applicant is requesting a waiver of the knowledge test for a hazardous materials endorsement
    *   Has not simultaneously held more than one civilian license (in addition to a military license)
    *   Has not had any license suspended, revoked, or cancelled
    *   Has not had any convictions for any type of motor vehicle for the disqualifying offenses contained in § 383.51(b)
    *   Has not had more than one conviction for any type of motor vehicle for serious traffic violations contained in § 383.51(c)
    *   Has not had any conviction for a violation of military, State or local law relating to motor vehicle traffic control (other than a parking violation) arising in connection with any traffic crash, and has no record of a crash in which he/she was at fault.

Output:
Yes, in some instances, fees may be waived. For a DUI hearing, the $375 fee may be waived if you're found to be indigent and have an income below the poverty threshold.

o If you feel there are other factors to consider in determining your eligibility, complete an Additional Eligibility Determination form. You may still qualify for assistance with your fee. If so, we'll notify you in writing.

Instruction: What is the difference between a farm labor vehicle certificate and a certification?
Output: A farm labor vehicle *certificate* is required for any person who drives farm labor trucks and buses. Upon successful completion of training, the California Highway Patrol (CHP) will issue a *verification* of training, valid for three years, which must be carried by the person when operating an implement of husbandry or a motor vehicle required to display placards. Within 15 days of issuance by the CHP, a copy of the verification must be forwarded to the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) for inclusion on the permanent driving record, along with a fee of $12.

Instruction: Can a farm labor vehicle certificate be used in place of a certification?

This verification is valid for three years and must be carried by the person when operating the vehicle. A copy of the verification must also be submitted to the Department of Motor Vehicles for inclusion on the person's permanent driving record. A farm labor vehicle certificate is not mentioned in the provided context.

Instruction: How does the DMV determine the eligibility criteria for a farm labor vehicle certificate or certification?
Output:
The DMV, in conjunction with the California Highway Patrol (CHP), determines eligibility for certain farm labor vehicle certifications based on these criteria:
Hazardous Agricultural Materials (HAM) Certificate:
*   The person is at least 21 years of age.
*   The person is employed in an agricultural operation.
*   The load is not being transported for compensation.
*   The vehicle is owned or leased by a farmer.
*   The person has completed a HAM program approved by CHP.
*   The person submits a copy of the Medical Examination Report (MER) and Medical Examiner’s Certificate (MEC) or Health Questionnaire (DL 546) form(s) to DMV every 2 years.
*   The person operates a vehicle which is an implement of husbandry or requires a noncommercial Class C DL and does not exceed 50 miles from one point to another.
Exemption from endorsement requirements of Section 15275:
*   The person is employed in an agricultural operation and is driving a vehicle, other than a vehicle used in common or contract motor carriage, controlled by a farmer and transporting agricultural products or farm machinery or supplies to or from a farm.
*   The person has fulfilled the applicable training requirements of Subpart H of Part 172 of Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations.
*   The person has, within the vehicle, informational material approved by the Department of the California Highway Patrol, in both English and Spanish, outlining basic safety procedures to be followed in the event of an accident.
*   The person is operating a vehicle which is an implement of husbandry or a motor vehicle requiring only a class C driver’s license and the distance which the vehicle is being operated is not more than 50 miles.
*   An applicant for a certificate submits medical information on a form approved by the department upon application and every two years thereafter.
Restricted Class A Driver’s License:
*   The vehicle is controlled and operated by a farmer.
*   The vehicle is used to transport livestock to or from a farm.
*   The vehicle is not used in the operations of a common or contract carrier.
*   The vehicle is used within 150 miles of the person’s farm.
*   An applicant submits medical information on a form approved by the department upon application and every two years thereafter.

The DMV determines eligibility for paratransit and school bus certifications based on several factors:
General Public Paratransit Vehicle (GPPV) Certificate: This is required for drivers of vehicles carrying not more than 24 persons, including the driver, providing local transportation to the general public, transporting pupils at or below the 12th grade level to or from school or school activities, or vehicles used in the exclusive transportation of disabled persons.
School Bus Driver Certificate: This is required for any person who drives a bus for any school district or other party carrying public or private pupils. A school bus driver must also have an “S” endorsement on their Commercial Driver's License (CDL). School bus drivers 65 years of age and older must submit annual Medical Examination Report (MER) and Medical Examiner's Certificate (MEC) forms to the DMV.
School Pupil Activity Bus Certificate (SPAB): This is required for any person who drives a bus for any school district or other party carrying public or private pupils for school-related activities.
Additional requirements include:
Driving Record: A person may not operate a school bus for the transportation of students unless the person's driving record is acceptable according to minimum standards. A check of the person's driving record is made annually.
Safety Education: A person must be certified in school bus safety education or enrolled in a school bus safety education class.
Criminal History Record Check: Before a person is employed to operate a school bus to transport students, the employer must obtain a criminal history record check.

Instruction: Can the specialized operator program be waived?
Output: For current or former military service members, a State may waive the requirements to pass a driving skills test and a specialized knowledge test for a passenger (P) endorsement; waive the requirements to pass a specialized knowledge test for a tank vehicle (N) endorsement; or waive the requirements to pass a specialized knowledge test for a hazardous materials (H) endorsement, provided they meet certain conditions and limitations. The service member must certify and provide evidence that, during the 1-year period immediately prior to the application, he/she: was regularly employed in a military position requiring operation of a passenger CMV, if requesting a waiver of the knowledge and driving skills test for a passenger endorsement; operation of a tank vehicle, if requesting a waiver of the knowledge test for a tank vehicle endorsement; or transportation of hazardous materials, if requesting a waiver of the knowledge test for a hazardous materials endorsement; has not simultaneously held more than one civilian license (in addition to a military license); has not had any license suspended, revoked, or cancelled; has not had any convictions for any type of motor vehicle for the disqualifying offenses; has not had more than one conviction for any type of motor vehicle for serious traffic violations; and has not had any conviction for a violation of military, State or local law relating to motor vehicle traffic control (other than a parking violation) arising in connection with any traffic crash, and has no record of a crash in which he/she was at fault.

Instruction: What is the process for obtaining a waiver for the specialized operator program?
Output:
To obtain a waiver for the specialized operator program, current or former military service members must meet specific conditions and limitations. A state may waive the requirement to pass a specialized knowledge test for a passenger (P) endorsement, a tank vehicle (N) endorsement, or a hazardous materials (H) endorsement if the applicant meets the criteria.
The conditions and limitations include:
1.  The applicant must be a current or former military service member as defined in § 383.5.
2.  The applicant must certify and provide evidence that, during the 1-year period immediately prior to the application, he/she:
    *   Was regularly employed in a military position requiring operation of a passenger CMV (if seeking a passenger endorsement waiver), operation of a tank vehicle (if seeking a tank vehicle endorsement waiver), or transportation of hazardous materials (if seeking a hazardous materials endorsement waiver).
    *   Has not simultaneously held more than one civilian license (in addition to a military license).
    *   Has not had any license suspended, revoked, or cancelled.
    *   Has not had any convictions for any type of motor vehicle for the disqualifying offenses contained in § 383.51(b).
    *   Has not had more than one conviction for any type of motor vehicle for serious traffic violations contained in § 383.51(c).
    *   Has not had any conviction for a violation of military, State, or local law relating to motor vehicle traffic control (other than a parking violation) arising in connection with any traffic crash, and has no record of a crash in which he/she was at fault.
If all these conditions are met, a state may waive the specialized knowledge test for the relevant endorsement.

The criteria for determining eligibility for a waiver are as follows:
Knowledge test waivers for certain current or former military service members applying for a CLP or CDL require that the applicant certify and provide evidence that, during the 1-year period immediately prior to the application, he/she:
*Is or was regularly employed and designated as a Motor Transport Operator—88M (Army); PATRIOT Launching Station Operator—14T (Army); Fueler—92F (Army); Vehicle Operator—2T1 (Air Force); Fueler—2F0 (Air Force); Pavement and Construction Equipment Operator—3E2 (Air Force); Motor Vehicle Operator—3531 (Marine Corps); or Equipment Operator—E.O. (Navy).
*Is operating a vehicle representative of the CMV type the driver applicant expects to operate upon separation from the military, or operated such a vehicle type immediately preceding separation from the military.
*Has not simultaneously held more than one civilian license (in addition to a military license).
*Has not had any license suspended, revoked, or cancelled.
*Has not had any convictions for any type of motor vehicle for the disqualifying offenses contained in § 383.51(b).
*Has not had more than one conviction for any type of motor vehicle for serious traffic violations contained in § 383.51(c).
*Has not had any conviction for a violation of military, State, or local law relating to motor vehicle traffic control (other than a parking violation) arising in connection with any traffic accident, and has no record of an accident in which he/she was at fault.
Driving skills test waivers for certain current or former military service members applying for a CDL require that the applicant provide evidence and certify that he/she:
*Is regularly employed or was regularly employed within the last year in a military position requiring operation of a CMV.
*Was exempted from the CDL requirements in § 383.3(c).
*Was operating a vehicle representative of the CMV type the driver applicant operates or expects to operate, for at least the 2 years immediately preceding separation from the military.
*Has not simultaneously held more than one civilian license (in addition to a military license).
*Has not had any license suspended, revoked, or cancelled.
*Has not had any convictions for any type of motor vehicle for the disqualifying offenses contained in § 383.51(b).
*Has not had more than one conviction for any type of motor vehicle for serious traffic violations contained in § 383.51(c).
*Has not had any conviction for a violation of military, State or local law relating to motor vehicle traffic control (other than a parking violation) arising in connection with any traffic crash, and has no record of a crash in which he/she was at fault.
Endorsement waivers for certain current or former military service members applying for a CLP or a CDL require that the applicant certify and provide evidence that, during the 1-year period immediately prior to the application, he/she:
*Is or was regularly employed in a military position requiring operation of a passenger CMV, if the applicant is requesting a waiver of the knowledge and driving skills test for a passenger endorsement; operation of a tank vehicle, if the applicant is requesting a waiver of the knowledge test for a tank vehicle endorsement; or transportation of hazardous materials, if the applicant is requesting a waiver of the knowledge test for a hazardous materials endorsement.
*Has not simultaneously held more than one civilian license (in addition to a military license).
*Has not had any license suspended, revoked, or cancelled.
*Has not had any convictions for any type of motor vehicle for the disqualifying offenses contained in § 383.51(b).
*Has not had more than one conviction for any type of motor vehicle for serious traffic violations contained in § 383.51(c).
*Has not had any conviction for a violation of military, State or local law relating to motor vehicle traffic control (other than a parking violation) arising in connection with any traffic crash, and has no record of a crash in which he/she was at fault.

Instruction: What is the process for obtaining a waiver?
Output:
The process for obtaining a waiver depends on the type of waiver you are seeking.
Military Knowledge Test Waiver:
For current or former military service members, a state may waive the requirement to pass the knowledge test for a Commercial Learner's Permit (CLP) or Commercial Driver's License (CDL) if the applicant meets certain conditions. The service member must certify and provide evidence that, during the one-year period before applying, they were regularly employed in a military position as a Motor Transport Operator (Army 88M), PATRIOT Launching Station Operator (Army 14T), Fueler (Army 92F), Vehicle Operator (Air Force 2T1), Fueler (Air Force 2F0), Pavement and Construction Equipment Operator (Air Force 3E2), Motor Vehicle Operator (Marine Corps 3531), or Equipment Operator (Navy E.O.). They must also be operating a vehicle representative of the CMV type they expect to operate after leaving the military, have no more than one civilian license (in addition to a military license), have no license suspensions, revocations, or cancellations, have no convictions for disqualifying offenses or more than one conviction for serious traffic violations, and have no convictions for traffic violations related to a crash where they were at fault.
Military Skills Test Waiver:
A state may waive the requirement for military service members to pass a driving skills test and specialized knowledge test for a passenger (P) endorsement, the knowledge test for a tank vehicle (N) endorsement, or the knowledge test for a hazardous materials (H) endorsement. The service member must certify and provide evidence that, during the one-year period before applying, they were regularly employed in a military position requiring the operation of a passenger CMV, a tank vehicle, or the transportation of hazardous materials. They must also meet the same conditions regarding licenses, convictions, and traffic violations as mentioned above.
DUI Hearing Fee Waiver:
In some states, if you are requesting a hearing for a Driving Under the Influence (DUI) sanction, you may apply for a waiver of the hearing fee if you are indigent and have an income below the poverty threshold. You must complete a DUI Administrative Hearing Fee Waiver Application and provide any additional information to support your eligibility.

7.  Background Checks: Passing a Transportation Security Administration (TSA) background check is required for a hazardous materials endorsement.
8.  Citizenship or Residency: Providing proof of U.S. citizenship or lawful permanent residency.

Instruction: What is the process for obtaining a waiver?

The process for obtaining a waiver depends on the type of waiver you are seeking.
Military Knowledge Test Waiver:

Military Skills Test Waiver:

Instruction: How does the DMV determine the eligibility of an individual for a waiver?
Output:
For current or former military service members applying for a Commercial Learner's Permit (CLP) or Commercial Driver's License (CDL), the DMV determines eligibility for a waiver based on specific conditions and limitations. To waive the knowledge test, the applicant must certify and provide evidence that, in the year before applying, they were regularly employed in specific military roles such as Motor Transport Operator, PATRIOT Launching Station Operator, Fueler, Vehicle Operator, Pavement and Construction Equipment Operator, or Equipment Operator. They must have operated a vehicle representative of the CMV type they expect to operate, held no more than one civilian license, and had no license suspensions, revocations, or cancellations. They must also have no convictions for disqualifying offenses or more than one conviction for serious traffic violations, and no convictions for traffic violations related to a crash where they were at fault.
To waive the driving skills test, the applicant must provide evidence and certify they were regularly employed in a military position requiring CMV operation within the past year, were exempt from CDL requirements, and operated a representative CMV for at least two years before separating from the military. They must also meet the same criteria regarding licenses, convictions, and traffic violations as for the knowledge test waiver, but over a two-year period.
For endorsement waivers, the applicant must certify and provide evidence that in the year before applying, they were regularly employed in a military position requiring operation of a passenger CMV, tank vehicle, or transportation of hazardous materials, depending on the endorsement sought. They must meet the same criteria regarding licenses, convictions, and traffic violations as for the knowledge test waiver.

Instruction: What is the process for obtaining a waiver?
Output:
The process for obtaining a waiver depends on the type of waiver you are seeking.
Military Knowledge Test Waiver:
For current or former military service members, a state may waive the requirement to pass a knowledge test for a Commercial Learner's Permit (CLP) or Commercial Driver's License (CDL) if the applicant meets specific conditions. The service member must certify and provide evidence that, in the year before applying, they were regularly employed in a military position as a Motor Transport Operator (Army 88M), PATRIOT Launching Station Operator (Army 14T), Fueler (Army 92F), Vehicle Operator (Air Force 2T1), Fueler (Air Force 2F0), Pavement and Construction Equipment Operator (Air Force 3E2), Motor Vehicle Operator (Marine Corps 3531), or Equipment Operator (Navy E.O.). They must also be operating a vehicle representative of the CMV type they expect to operate after leaving the military, held no more than one civilian license in addition to their military license, have had no license suspensions, revocations, or cancellations, have no convictions for disqualifying offenses or more than one conviction for serious traffic violations, and have no convictions for traffic violations related to a crash where they were at fault.
Military Skills Test Waiver:
A state may waive the requirement for military service members to pass a driving skills test or specialized knowledge test for a passenger (P) endorsement, knowledge test for a tank vehicle (N) endorsement, or knowledge test for a hazardous materials (H) endorsement, if the applicant meets certain conditions. They must certify and provide evidence that, in the year before applying, they were regularly employed in a military position requiring operation of a passenger CMV (for a passenger endorsement waiver), operation of a tank vehicle (for a tank vehicle endorsement waiver), or transportation of hazardous materials (for a hazardous materials endorsement waiver). They must also meet the same criteria regarding licenses, convictions, and traffic violations as mentioned above for the knowledge test waiver.
DUI Hearing Fee Waiver:
In some states, such as Washington, you can apply for a waiver of the $375 DUI hearing fee if you are found to be indigent and have an income below the poverty threshold. To apply, you must submit a Request for DUI Hearing form, a DUI Administrative Hearing Fee Waiver Application, and potentially an Additional Eligibility Determination form.

The criteria for determining eligibility for a waiver are as follows:
Knowledge test waivers for certain current or former military service members applying for a CLP or CDL require that the applicant certify and provide evidence that, during the 1-year period immediately prior to the application, he/she:
*Is or was regularly employed and designated as a Motor Transport Operator—88M (Army); PATRIOT Launching Station Operator—14T (Army); Fueler—92F (Army); Vehicle Operator—2T1 (Air Force); Fueler—2F0 (Air Force); Pavement and Construction Equipment Operator—3E2 (Air Force); Motor Vehicle Operator—3531 (Marine Corps); or Equipment Operator—E.O. *Has not had any conviction for a violation of military, State or local law relating to motor vehicle traffic control (other than a parking violation) arising in connection with any traffic crash, and has no record of a crash in which he/she was at fault.
Endorsement waivers for certain current or former military service members applying for a CLP or a CDL require that the applicant certify and provide evidence that, during the 1-year period immediately prior to the application, he/she:
*Is or was regularly employed in a military position requiring operation of a passenger CMV, if the applicant is requesting a waiver of the knowledge and driving skills test for a passenger endorsement; operation of a tank vehicle, if the applicant is requesting a waiver of the knowledge test for a tank vehicle endorsement; or transportation of hazardous materials, if the applicant is requesting a waiver of the knowledge test for a hazardous materials endorsement
*Has not simultaneously held more than one civilian license (in addition to a military license)
*Has not had any license suspended, revoked, or cancelled

For current or former military service members, as defined in § 383.5, the DMV determines eligibility for a waiver based on specific conditions and limitations. To be eligible for a waiver of the knowledge test for a Commercial Learner's Permit (CLP) or Commercial Driver's License (CDL), an applicant must certify and provide evidence that, during the 1-year period immediately prior to the application, he/she:
*   Is or was regularly employed and designated as a Motor Transport Operator—88M (Army), PATRIOT Launching Station Operator—14T (Army), Fueler—92F (Army), Vehicle Operator—2T1 (Air Force), Fueler—2F0 (Air Force), Pavement and Construction Equipment Operator—3E2 (Air Force), Motor Vehicle Operator—3531 (Marine Corps), or Equipment Operator—E.O. To be eligible for a waiver of the driving skills test, the State shall impose conditions and limitations to restrict the applicants from whom a State may accept alternative requirements for the driving skills test described in § 383.113. Such conditions must require at least the following:
*   An applicant must provide evidence and certify that he/she:
*   Is regularly employed or was regularly employed within the last year in a military position requiring operation of a CMV;

*   An applicant must certify that, during the 2-year period immediately prior to applying for a CDL, he/she:
*   Has not simultaneously held more than one civilian license (in addition to a military license);
*   Has not had any license suspended, revoked, or cancelled;
*   Has not had any convictions for any type of motor vehicle for the disqualifying offenses contained in § 383.51(b);
*   Has not had more than one conviction for any type of motor vehicle for serious traffic violations contained in § 383.51(c); and
*   Has not had any conviction for a violation of military, State or local law relating to motor vehicle traffic control (other than a parking violation) arising in connection with any traffic crash, and has no record of a crash in which he/she was at fault.
To be eligible for a waiver of the driving skills test or the specialized knowledge test for a passenger carrier endorsement, the knowledge test for the tank vehicle endorsement, or the knowledge test for the hazardous materials endorsement, a current or former military service member must certify and provide evidence that, during the 1-year period immediately prior to the application, he/she:
*   Is or was regularly employed in a military position requiring operation of a passenger CMV, if the applicant is requesting a waiver of the knowledge and driving skills test for a passenger endorsement; operation of a tank vehicle, if the applicant is requesting a waiver of the knowledge test for a tank vehicle endorsement; or transportation of hazardous materials, if the applicant is requesting a waiver of the knowledge test for a hazardous materials endorsement.
*   Has not simultaneously held more than one civilian license (in addition to a military license).
*   Has not had any license suspended, revoked, or cancelled.
*   Has not had any convictions for any type of motor vehicle for the disqualifying offenses contained in § 383.51(b).
*   Has not had more than one conviction for any type of motor vehicle for serious traffic violations contained in § 383.51(c).
*   Has not had any conviction for a violation of military, State or local law relating to motor vehicle traffic control (other than a parking violation) arising in connection with any traffic crash, and has no record of a crash in which he/she was at fault.
